Its irritating head opens a glaring red eye: the red flag pops across the entire screen:
CLOSEUP of a pipe cutter attached to the meter neck, meta slivers curling out. From o.s. we HEAR -- LUCAS JACKSON  cheerfully humming and mumbling Auld Lang Syne and then:
Okay, Mister General, you son of a  bitch. Sir. Think you can put things  right with a piece of tin with a  ribbon hangin' on it? Gonna put you  right.
as the meter head falls out of FRAME.

as it falls to the ground amidst a forest of meter stands and Luke's hand comes into the FRAME to pick it up and we SEE him in CLOSEUP for the first time. He is cheerful, dr wearing a faded GI Field jacket. A bottle opener hangs on silver chain around his neck. He addresses the next meter
All right. Helen, honey. I lost my  head over you. Now its your turn.
Suddenly the beam of headlights crashes in, FLARING the  SCREEN.
sliding up to us, headlights glaring, red toplight revolv menacingly. TWO OFFICERS, black shapes, get out and start warily toward Luke.
illuminated by the headlights. He grins as the Officers  approach, lifts a bottle of beer, opens it and drinks,  smiling. On his smile, FREEZE FRAME. ON THE FRAME SUPER-I MAIN TITLE and as it FADES

It swings with a pendulum motion, its shining blade toppi a clump of grass and weeds; it swings on the backstroke,  lopping more grass, then moves a little away from CAMERA. FROM CAMERA RIGHT, a pair of feet move INTO the FRAME, th feet of the man swinging the yoyo. They are booted and  connected by chains, riveted around the ankles. The feet  move further INTO the FRAME and the SHOT WIDENS. We are o

and we see the work gang in uniforms (14 men) flailing aw with yoyos, short-handled scythes in the hot sun, guarded three men. Three of the workers wear chains (Gambler,  Dynamite, Sailor). The scene is bleached and hot; the men sweating and dirty in prison shirts and pants. The light  shifts during the following:
He is a trustee. He walks up INTO CAMERA and sets up sign
He is a giant, covered with sweat and dust. He starts to  pull off his shirt.
Takin' it off here, Boss!
Yeah, take it off, Dragline!
pulling out watch, looking at the sun.
flailing away, most of them naked to the waist.
He is sweating streams.
Wipin' it off here, Boss!
Okay, wipe it off there, Koko.
Koko takes out a limp handkerchief and mops his face.
his yoyo flashing like a sword. He pauses, panting.
Drinkin' it up here, Boss!
Awright, drink it up, Gambler. Water  'em, Rabbit.
as Gambler takes a drink from a tin cup, passed by Rabbit
working away like a machine.
Godfrey is the Walking Boss, silent, implacable symbol of ultimate judgement. He wears a black hat, globular mirror sunglasses -- the Man With No Eyes, impassive, emotionles He nods to Boss Shorty.
Awright, smoke it up!
In unison they chant:
Yeah, Boss.
Society is checking his yoyo edge with a file, covertly  watching a passing car. Blind Dick sneaks a look, then du
You eyeballin' there, Society?
Checkin' my yoyo, Boss!
He sees something o.s. He speaks, as they all do outside, like a ventriloquist, not moving the lips, and in a stage whisper, to Dragline.
Drag... Drag... Newmeat Bus! We got  us Newmeat tonight!
They look up covertly.
The Newmeat Bus, a prison vehicle, a panel truck with mes windows; and men in it, appears down the road approaching the gang. It slows as it passes them and the men covertly look at it.
(whispering) A bunch. Must be halfa dozen Newmeat.
No more than five. For a cold drink.
(whispering) Bet! Babalugats, bet here!
He is the idiot of the gang. He grins foolishly, making t bet official.
as it passes, picking up speed, PAN INTO:
looking at the Newmeat Bus.
His sunglasses FILL THE SCREEN, distorting the image of t bus as it moves away from us and the last TITLE ROLLS.

The SCREEN is mostly black, but we see out through the me rear windows a desolate panorama of gnarled trees and gru landscape, bleak and hopeless. Now we HEAR outside the barking and baying of bloodhounds not like they're tracking, but just playing as the truck  turns and stops. The BUS GUARD and DRIVER get out. The ba of the truck is opened by the guard and through that rect of bright sunlight, the silhouettes of the Newmeat descen Luke last.

The Scene: in a hollow is a long barracks, white-washed,  faded gray, one story high. At right is a mess hall and  laundry. A chain-link fence surrounds the whole compound. The corners of the fence are telephone poles with floodli on the tops. These burn all night. Back of the mess hall, again outside the fence, are several kennel runs in which bloodhounds are now ROARING. A wooden tower with a simple board roof stands at two corners of the compound where th guards sit when the prisoners are not locked in the barra A picnic table sits in a grassy area just outside and at side of the gate is a picket fence enclosing a scrubby la
Four. Right.
He hands the papers to the CAPTAIN, a small man with a ki face but a firm, set mouth who always carries a golf club In b.g. the bloodhounds are YOWLING:
Dogboy, get them dogs shut up!
DOGBOY, a trustee whose leather gloves are always stickin out of one back pocket, puts his hand to be licked by the dogs who quiet, friendly, like any pets.
They just smell newmeat is all, Boss.
The Captain has been ignoring this, watching the prisoner looking at their records.
as the Bosses (BOSS PAUL and BOSS HIGGINS) motion for the the other Newmeat (to be known as TRAMP, ALIBI, and TATTO stumble into each other and jostle Luke in their eagernes to obey orders.
You men git lined up here.

The Newmeat jostle into line. They are wearing State Issu gray pants and their own Free World shirts. All except Lu carry a paper bag or cigar box containing their wordly go All except Luke look apprehensive, worried. Luke stands w languid grace, neither insolent nor hostile, nor fearful. The Bus Guard hands Boss Paul a folder that contains reco as the Captain approaches from his porch.
What did they bring us today? Gibson.  A 507, Manslaughter. Good for a two  spot.
It was an accident. I've never been  in any trouble.
You'all call the Captain, Captain.
(to next man) Edgar Potter. A 302 and resisting  arrest. One year.
I was tryin' to keep outa the rain.
Git the wax out'n yore ears. You  call the Captain, Captain.
Yes, sir.
And you call the rest of us Boss,  you hear?
Yes, Boss.
This man is gonna make us proud of  him, Mr. Hunnicutt. (moving on) Raymond Pratt.
Yes, Captain.
Breakin', enterin' and assault. Five  spot. Hmmm. Able-bodied seaman.
That oughta come in handy here,  Captain.
Maybe. (turning to Luke) Lucas Jackson.
Here, Captain.
Maliciously destroyin' municipal  property while under the influence.  What was that?
Cuttin' the heads off parkin' meters,  Captain.
Well, we ain't never had one of them.  Where'd you think that was gonna get  you?
I guess you could say I wasn't  thinkin', Captain.
(looking at record) Says here you done real good in the  war: Silver Star, Bronze Star, couple  Purple Hearts. Sergeant! Little time  in stockades. Come out the same way  you went in: Buck Private.
That's right, Captain. Just passin'  the time.

(staring at him) Well, you got yourself some time  now. Two years. Hell, that ain't  much, we got coupla men here doin'  twenty spots. We got one who's got  all of it. We got all kinds and you  gonna fit in real good. Course in  case you git rabbit in your blood  and decide to take off fer home, you  git a bonus a some time and couple  leg chains to keep you slowed down a  little -- fer your own good. You'll  learn the rules. It's all up to you.  I can be a good guy or I can be one  mean son-of-a-bitch, it's up to you.
He turns and walks away.
His eyes have been wandering during this speech. He sees doleful, lovable bloodhound, nose at the mesh and winks a him.
He simply stares dolefully.

Bare, unpainted wood. The windows are barred and covered  with chain link. The door from the barracks up to the com passes a small area enclosed by a woven metal strap cage. this usually sits the WICKER MAN, whom we generally see a heavy, short shape moving about his own business which is making an endless series of rings or jewelry by hammering coins with the back of a heavy spoon. The door to the barracks locks by the tongue of a strap i bar that is thrust through a hole in the wicker where the Wicker Man locks it by padlock. Thus he can always see th but they can't reach him. The single big room is filled w two and even three-tiered bunks. Bare bulbs hang from the ceiling. CARR, the floorwalker, a 240 pound behemoth, is indoctrin the Newmeat while they change into camp clothing: gray tw trousers, shirt and jacket, all numbered, which has been  piled on the table. Carr squeegees up and down, a restles man, and CAMERA in following him SHOWS us the room. At th same time, the Wicker Man is moving about the barracks,  tapping the floors and bunk posts with a broom handle for signs of tampering. Carr pays no attention to him, addres the Newmeat.

Them clothes has got laundry numbers  on 'em. You remember your number and  always wear the ones that has your  number. Any man forgets his number  spends a night in the box. (passing out spoons) This yere spoon you keep with you  and any man loses his spoon spends a  night in the box. There is no playing  grabass or fighting in the building.  You got a grudge against another man  you can fight him Saturday afternoon.  Any man playing grabass or fighting  in the building spends a night in  the box. First bell is at five minutes  of eight when you will get in your  bunk and last bell is at eight...
O.S. now are heard the SOUNDS of trucks arriving and the  Wicker Man goes back to the wicker.

(continuing) Any man not in his bunk at eight  will spend a night in the box. There  is no smoking in prone position in  bed. To smoke you must have both  legs over the side of your bunk.  Anyone caught smoking in prone  position will spend a night in the  box. You get two sheets. Every  Saturday you put the clean sheet on  the top, the top sheet on the bottom  and the bottom sheet you turn in to  the Laundry Boy. Any man who turns  in the wrong sheet spends a night in  the box. No one will sit on the bunks  with dirty pants on. Any man sitting  on a bunk with dirty pants will spend  a night in the box. Any man who don't  bring back his empty pop bottles  spends a night in the box.
O.S. now are the SOUNDS of men counting off, filling the with the apprehension of impending arrival.

(continuing) Any man loudtalking spends a night  in the box. You got questions you  come to me. (attentive now) I'm Carr, the floorwalker. I'm  responsible for order in here and  any man that don't keep order...
Luke mouths the next line with him. At the same time, we  HEAR the clanking of the Wicker Man's doors opening and t thudding of many steps.
...spends a night in the box. (to Luke, sincerely) I hope you ain't gonna be a hardcase.

As Luke shrugs the chute bursts open and the Bull Gang ru in, men trying to get hands clean, urinate and get back o into the chowline. Sudden LOUD CHAOS. The Newmeat are sea on the bench, bewildered, except Luke who grins. Koko spi the Newmeat and is unhappy that there are only four.
(to Koko) Four. You owe me a drink.
(pushing both aside) Get outa mah way you don't want a  wet pocket!
(passing the Newmeat) Gentlemen, welcome to the Family.
Any of you guys from Connecticut?
Awright, let's move it along!
as the flow of bodies reverses and the men stampede for t chute, going out, adjusting clothing, etc. Dragline shove Loudmouth Steve along.
Fill your loudmouth with some beans!
And they are in the chute. The Newmeat still sit there. . the empty barracks, the SOUND of men disappearing across yard.
Well, what are you doin' here? You  supposed to be eatin' them beans!
The Newmeat stampede out the chute.

Most of the other men already have their food and are sit down with no jockeying for places: everybody knows. They shoveling it down as fast as they can, getting back up fo seconds. Luke and the other Newmeat get their plates and  while the others stand there, confused, Luke sits at the  first vacant spot and begins to eat industriously.
(sotto voce to Dragline) Newmeat's a hog-gut.
Dragline looks up, goes back to his food. There is an off stage CRASH.

He is sitting on the floor, between his knees a mess of s on the floor and his plate upside down. He has made the  mistake of taking Dynamite's seat. DYNAMITE, the champion eater, has casually displaced him and is busy chowing. Do is serving; he is the only one to break the rule of silen in chowlines.
These pigs is rollin' in thar slops  now, Boss!
Tramp makes terrified and ineffectual efforts to scoop th stew back onto his plate with his hand, wiping his hand o his uniform, etc., then trying to obliterate the stain on the floor with a foot.

The men are being shaken down before entering the barrack for the night. They sit and take off their shoes. They em their pockets into their caps. Carr inspects shoes, throw them inside door, frisks men who stand with backs turned, arms raised. Then Carr mutters a number.
Through the Wicker Cage toward door. As the men enter, st to pick up shoes, repeat their number to the Wicker Man, they go through the chute.

The men are preparing for their hour of free time. Gamble has layed out the blanket for the poker game and is shuff cards. Koko and BLIND DICK have their seats, are arrangin their piles of change. Luke sits at the other end of the  table, past the blanket line. Dragline who has been talki to the Wicker Man now enters casually as we HEAR Dynamite change in hand, moving to the game berating Tramp.
Next time you stay outa my place! I  earned it. You try that agin an'  I'll bounce you all over the floor.
I didn't know. I was hungry.
You don't take another man's place,  boy.
It wasn't his fault. Nobody said  anything about seats. We --
(to Tramp) You gotta mind your manners, you  actin' like a hillbilly tramp.
(delighted) Tramp! Beautiful!
Dragline nods.
(to Tramp) You got your bullgang name, boy.
(good-naturedly) Ain't no worse than some I been  called.
In the Navy, we used to call guys --
Fasten your flap! All you Newmeats  gonna have to shape up fast and hard  on this gang. We got rules here an'  in order to learn them, you gotta  keep your ears open and your mouths  shut.
Luke snorts.
looking up as if he has just heard a strange sound.
Somebody say somethin'?
I didn't say nothin', Boss.
Well, whatta we got here?
A Lucas Jackson.
(at mirror, back turned) Dragline gives out the names here.  You'll get yours when he figures you  out.
(to Luke) Maybe we oughta call you No-Ears.  You don't listen much, do you, boy?
(smiling) Ain't heard much worth listening to  yet. Just everybody handing out rules.
A feeling of discomfort. Koko assesses Luke, who has rema at the poker table.
Newmeat looks like a poker player,  Drag.

Wouldn't surprise me none. (to Luke) Wicker Man says you got a hundred- twenny and some change in the  Captain's safe and you got your five  dollars pocket money... That'll buy  you a whole fistfull of cards. You  in or out?
Luke stares at him for a beat, then shrugs -- who needs i and walks over to his bunk.
Looks like you've got yourself a  redhot, Dragline.
Dragline just stares after Luke.
(dealing) Awright, let's play some poker. First  Jack is the Man... a trey, a duck, a  neighter...

He continues to call cards as we PAN AWAY and DOWN the bu showing Alibi writing a letter, Loudmouth Steve reading a sex book, STUPID BLONDIE working a rattleskin wallet, SAI removing his pants through his chains, CHIEF rolling  cigarettes, etc.
The shadow of the Wicker Man behind it rises and moves to the tire rim which he beats with a tire iron.
First bell!
The men break it up, some head for the urinal.
He lies in his bunk staring directly into a flyspecked bu hanging from the ceiling about eighteen inches from his f It will be on all night. The tire iron SOUNDS again and m hurry for their bunks.
Last bell. Last bell.
Carr moves down the aisle, counting lips moving. The barr is silent. Finishing the count, Carr goes to the Wicker.
Fifty, Boss.
Fifty. Okay, Carr.
staring up at bulb.
Gittin' up here, Carr.
Pacing along, his feet squeegeeing on the floor.
Yeeahp.
In the sleeping barracks he gets up and moves toward the  toilets...
He is crouched in a tortured position to pray, in the spa between his bunk and the one above.
He rolls over and goes to sleep. SOUND OVER: Carr squeege along, the CREAK of the bunks as men toss and turn, the W RUNNING in the toilets, the DOGS BARKING a little outside

He sits at the poker table. The sound has dropped now in depth of the night, the chink, chink of the Wicker man  stopped. Carr simply sits staring at his half-finished ga of solitaire, a card in his hand, his eyes seeing somethi far distant. He's breathing but he could be carved of sto
All others sleeping. Carr at poker table. Suddenly the cl of the iron bar is HEARD.
First bell! First bell! Let's go!
as, still asleep, he is unceremoniously dumped onto the f by Carr who goes right by. Pandemonium of rushing men all around.
Carr is barring the gate with his body. The door outside unlocked and opened. The gong SOUNDS. Carr opens the gate steps outside to the porch and the men begin counting out
The voices continue to count off as the men run to locker and quickly line up outside the mess hall. Watching them is Boss Godfrey.
impassive behind the sunglasses.

head_text.subj: EXT. MESS HALL INSIDE YARD BEFORE DAWN, (NIGHT)

text: The men pour out. There is a little dawnlight, but the  floodlights are still on. The Yard Man opens the gate and the men begin counting off again. Gambler is the last out the mess hall and gets a kick in the ass from Boss Paul t get him up with the others.
He sits in his rocket watching. We hear the SOUND of the counting, clanging of chains.
The men clamber inside. The Little Bull Gang truck leaves
Caravan of the Little Bull Gang and Patch Squad trucks mo off down the road into the dawn light.
just as the gate is swung shut. We SEE Godfrey's face loo in, then all is dim and the truck begins to lurch away,  gunning fast, throwing the men, searching for their custo seats. Chaos.
Git outa my eyeballin' seat, you  Newmeat dummy!

Luke stands, holding a strut in the roof and watching wit amusement as Tattoo is shoved away by Dragline, then Koko and then pushed from man to man as he tries to sit down b always finds a lap in the way. Bawdy laughter; it's a gam but earnest. As they settle Tattoo winds up on the floor grins, understands, finds a place beside Tramp. Across th way Alibi begins a serious conversation with Blind Dick.
(nervously) Where are we going now?
It's the Captain's birthday. They're  takin' us on a picnic.
(uncertainly smiling) I'm a salesman. I used to drive these  roads all the time. I never thought --  it was an accident, car skidded,  maybe I'd had a drink or two --
Man! It's gonna be one hot muther  today.
Bears gonna be walkin' the road today.
(to Tattoo) You ever seen a man bearcaught?
Tattoo and Tramp look uncertain, frightened.
All the salt goes outa his body and  the water follers the salt and the  brain shrivels up like a dried pea.
(trying to ingratiate) When I was in the Navy --
(to Alibi) Convulsions, shivering. Very  unpleasant to watch.
(to Alibi) Man's never the same. Makes him lose  his sex drive.
(to Tramp) I'm lucky I got a broom. Work up  top. Real easy job. Man, it's gonna  be hot down in that ditch.
We work down in the ditch?
Ain't you never seen a chain gang,  in all your driving around?
(to Koko) I ain't used to hard labor neither.  Done my best to avoid it.
I ain't crazy about it myself.
(shaking his head) Gonna be a hot one to learn on.
Koko, why don't you let one of these  Newmeats take your broom for today?
Hell, no. I ain't goin' down in the  ditch.
I shore would appreciate it. I ain't  in much shape just now.
What about me?
(to Tramp and Tattoo) Perhaps if you offered Brother Koko  a small... (makes money gesture)
I ain't got much. A quarter?
(to Koko) You was to sell your job, maybe this  Lucas War Hero would give you a price.
I'll give you fifty cents.
Fifty cents? Sweet job like that  worth at least a buck.
I'll make it a dollar.
Buck is a deal.
(apologetically to  Tramp, Tattoo) I've got this weak heart. Too much  drinking, I guess. As soon as they  find out about it, they'll probably  send me someplace else.
If you even need dough in here, I'm  in big trouble.
(to Dragline) Where'd you get that about war hero?
Oh we got our sources... Tearing the  heads off... what was it... gumball  machines? What kind of thing is that  for a grown man?
(amused by the put-on) Well, you know. Small town, not much  to do in the evenings. Mostly it was  settling up old scores.
You'll have to do better than that  if you want to impress these men.  Some pretty hard numbers here.  Dragline's an ex-safe cracker, Koko's  a jewel thief. Blind Dick is a rapist.
(to Luke) Show you the clippings some time.  News-Dispatch called me "The Shiek  of Simmonsville." Five broads in  three days...
'Course two of them were sisters.

Of course some of them, like Stupid  Blondie, were just unlucky... he  fell off the fire escape... and one  or two don't really belong here at  all... (indicates Babalugats) ...or myself, who just made the small  error of misspelling a friend's  name... on a check.
Hey, Koko. You hear that? All this  time I been thinkin' Society just  come here for the sun and exercise.
Everyone laughs.
(to Luke who is smiling) Whatta you so happy about?
I just always did like truck rides.
as the trucks pull up and stop and the men pour out, pick up tools for the day's work.
The guards for the day are: Paul, Kean, Higgins and Godfr As the men move through the line for tools, Alibi approac Boss Paul:
Boss, I made an arrangement with  that man to take his broom.
(shoving him along) Git your shovel and git to work.
I don't think you understand. We  made a deal ---
(canes him on the leg) Git movin', I said.
(in pain) But I made this arrangement --
(shoving him) Cut that backsass!
Alibi sees the light, accepts a shovel and walks off  resentfully to where the others are working, casting hurt angry looks at Koko and Society who ignore him.
in Godfrey's glasses, and we SEE the gang begin their wor In VARIOUS CUTS, in each of which the sun leaps forward,  time passing inexorably...
rhythmically working away.
Trying to pretend to work, not doing it well and getting passing cut from Boss Paul's cane. Resentfully, he goes a it, sweating heavily.
He is working hard but badly, unused to the awkward tool, trying to master it. Society Red works up behind him.
You're working too hard. You won't  last two hours. Watch the way the  Human Dragline does it.
He is whipping away with apparently effortless ease but  accomplishing more than the others.
An open red Continental with kit zips past, the driver  grinning at the Gang.
He is suffering along, sweat pouring off him. The sun is  beginning to really beat down now. Dragline works a littl behind him.
Takin' it off here, Boss!
Yeah, take it off there.
He takes off his jacket and tosses it to the edge of the  road where Dogboy collects it. Tattoo decides to imitate, tentatively.
Takin' it off here, Boss?
Yeah, take if off there.
He strips, revealing a tattoo of "Mother" lodged thornlik in his flesh and a great garland of flowers and a girl on his chest.
(sotto voce) Hey, turn around! Let Koko see the  broad.
turning so Koko can see, grinning, stopping work.
Beautiful! A real work of art!
(low voice) Nice broad. Good set.
(proudly, flexing it) Had it done in Singapore. Bunch of  us drunk as coots --
(hissing) Hey, Tattoo!
(not hearing) -- went down to see this old hag and  she had needles the size of that  cane.
(quietly) Hey. Swing that yoyo or you gonna  get a taste of that cane.
Tattoo realizes where he is and goes back to work.
as he seems to spin, his eyes closed, his arms limp, his  head lolling back, he stumbles, twists, careens.
seeing this.
Man bearcaught, boss!
Blondie... Sleepy! Git him afore he  falls.
They drop their tools and rush over as Tramp falls. Witho ceremony, they drag him over the rough ground to the truc where Boss Paul locks him in.
He is watching Luke, who is very close to the same fate.  Although he has achieved some grace, it is apparent that  Luke is working too strenuously, too determined.
He reaches into his pocket and takes out a turnip watch,  looks to Godfrey, who nods.
Awright, let's eat them beans!
The men break and head for the chow line.
He has dropped to the ground, examining a blister on his  hand. At Boss Kean's call, he looks up, ruefully resentfu and gets to his feet and slowly walks to the chow line.
Hey, you. Bean time!
(eyeing Luke, to  Gambler) Cold drink he don't make it.
Bet. Babalugats, bet!
Babalugats grins. Dragline has his chow, passes Luke.
(whispering) You got to snag it, man. You got to  stop foolin' around and tear up them  weeds.
Luke stumbles past, not paying attention.
It is later in the afternoon.
He stops.
Caught short here, boss!
Awright, Blondie. Take it behind  that tree.
He drops his tool and gratefully trots off in the directi of the tree.
It is later. He is working hard, stops a minute as he HEA a crow cawing overhead. He looks up at it.
He snaps his fingers.
looking up as Rabbitt goes to the truck and gets out a si action rifle which he brings to Godfrey, who puts in a bo and bullets from his pocket.
Who's that?
Boss Godfrey.
The walking boss.
Don't he ever talk?
Godfrey has raised the gun and now FIRES.
It is hit, explodes in a burst of feathers.
I believe he just said something.
working, Luke flailing away like an automaton.

as it is opened from the outside. Tramp sits up against t bench, still in rocky shape from his collapse. The others step over him as though he weren't there. Luke appears, l a sleepwalker. He grabs the side rails, gets one foot up tries to pull himself over the edge of the truck body. Bu the muscles are just used up. Boss Paul sees this and giv Luke a kick, timed so that it coincides with his jump. It gives him just the added momentum needed to send him over the edge of the body and sprawling along the floor. He's last one and as the guards lock them up, he grins up at  Dragline and Gambler from his prone position.
(to Dragline) You owe that fella a cold drink.
The men are not tired, they smoke and talk and laugh: it' been an easy day.
Hot damn, Drag. Tomorrow's Saturday.  Another week almost made.
(hopelessly) I got two years.
Only two? Man, I already done eight.  Nothin' to it. Just make the days  and let the weeks and the years make  themselves.
I did three hitches in the Navy. It  ain't bad. After a while, you get  used to it and the time --
Koko is looking out the back of the truck.
Oh, man, oh man. Look at that. On  the bicycle. Lookit them shorts. I'm  dyin'.
The men rush to look out at the vision of freedom on the  bike.

(knowledgeably) She looks just like a lil girl I  useta know named Louise Merryweather.  Fine lil ol' girl, always partial to  home-made whiskey. Remember one time  down in the cellar, both of us knee- walkin' drunk and ah had this lil  pint and Louise wanted a poke of it.  So ah said: you wanna poke and I  wanna poke, so...
He starts his story. On the floor, Luke sleeps.

as they are counting in through the gate, their hats with their personal possessions in them held out to be inspect their pockets turned out. A guard frisks them quickly but efficiently. The Captain stands nearby ignoring them, tes a golf swing. The men move to the mess hall, most of them the run. Luke moves painfully with exhaustion. Alibi seem quiet and cowed, lost in the crowd. They fall into a line the mess hall door. Dynamite, his spoon out, moves to the front of the line and Luke winds up somewhere near the re
(yardman) Awright, you, Gibson, step out. Boss  Paul says you wasn't happy with your  job. Done a lot of complainin'. Gone  give you a chance to think it over.
Alibi looks around, fearfully steps out, peering up and d the line, wondering.
Get them clothes off.

Alibi is led to the box. A light stands about it shining  down into it and it always burns when the box is ready to used or when there's someone inside. Now a nightshirt is  laid out on top of it. Alibi strips and puts on the pajam Boss Kean opens the heavy lid of the box and we see it is grilled with heavy chain link fencing and with strap iron bars. A chamber pot is put inside. Alibi stands in the bo looking back at them, then lies down out of sight. The li is slammed shut.
The men watching this. The mess hall door opens and they  begin to file in.
as the Wicker Man whales away at his tire rim outside the barracks.
Awright, first bell! Let's hit them  bunks!
The men are piling into bunks and the CAMERA FINDS Luke  heaving himself with a kind of rueful amusement up to the third tier bunk he sleeps in; he's exhausted.
Plumb busted out. Looks like the  hard road finally got to Mister Lucas  War Hero.
(agreeably) Back at it in the mornin'. Just need  a little nap...
He lies back. Across him and in various perspectives are other participants in this conversation, speaking in the  ventriloquist's whisper while the stragglers get into the sack.
Man, I never thought they'd put him  in the box on his first day.
It was just supposed to be a joke.  There ain't no brooms. Whoever heard  of a chain gang using brooms?
I gotta tell you that I believed it.
He should have known; it was a gag.
You can't switch 'round jobs, anyway.  I figured he knew that.
You can't expect him to learn  everything the first day. Hopefully  it's taught him a very valuable  lesson.
Well, you fixed it up so he's got  all night to think about it.
It's not our fault he's a square.

Course not. He ain't in the box 'cause  a the joke played on him. He's there  'cause he back sassed a Free Man.  They got their rules and we ain't  got nothing to do with that. Woulda  probably happened to him sooner or  later, to a complainer like him.  He's gotta learn the rules same as  anybody else.
Yeah, those poor old guards need all  the help they can get.
You tryin' to say somethin'?
Luke rolls over and goes to sleep.
(to his back) You jus' keep flapping your mouth  and one of these times, you and me  gonna raise a little dust.
The Wicker Man begins hitting the tire rim again.
Awright, last bell!
Silence.
(continuing) Forty-nine and one in the box, Boss!
Forty-nine and one in the box. Right,  Carr.

It slashes away like a pendulum, golden in the sun, TICKI away time, over roads that stretch to infinity -- a SHOT  that will always tell us that the men are building time.  SHOT WIDENS. The gang is laboring, filling in washouts by the roadside. The bosses are Paul, Kean, Higgins, and, al Godfrey, the Walking Boss.

He is tanned and hardened now, and has mastered the work  rhythm. SHOT WIDENS to show Dragline near him, checking h shovel for nicks but really eyeballing a passing car. In ditch, Luke expertly scoops up a shovel full of sand and, levering the handle on his knee, flips the sand through t air so it hits spang in the pan of Dragline's shovel whil Dragline is still eyeballing. It knocks him off balance a by the time he has caught up, Luke is already catching hi with another shovel full.
Slow down, man. They ain't passing  out medals for slinging dirt.
I thought you knew, boy... they  sentenced me by the mile.
Dragline grins at this insouciance, sneaks a look down th road. He digs into his pocket and hauls out a pair of sal sunglasses, which he holds up.
Puttin' 'em on here, Boss!
Yeah, put 'em on, Drag!
as Dragline hooks on the glasses. Luke, Tattoo and Tramp working around here.
(to Tramp) Lookit that. Some Hollywood movie  star jus' joined up with us.
Tramp smiles.
(to Koko) Man, this here Newmeat parking meter  bandit thing what calls itself Luke  don't know nuthin' 'bout nuthin'.
(to Tramp) But damn if he don't look like a fat  old Dragline.
Coulda fooled me.
(to Tattoo) These is my eyeballin' glasses. Now  I'm gonna play peek-a-boo and ol'  Godfrey ain't gonna know if I'm  eyeballin' or tootin' the piccolo.
That ain't nuthing compared to what  we used to do in San Pedro. There  was this ensign...
(has been sniffing  the air) Ah believe I smell me a blonde-haired  lady.

They all look up covertly and, sure enough, in the second car slowed down by Rabbit's sign, is a lush BLONDE in a s dress that is hiked up high on the thighs and cut low ove the bosom. She cringes under their gaze and starts the to going up on the car as though to hide from them.
Man, see her legs. She's tanned all  over.
Nice broad. Nice set.
She looks just like Mrs. Patricia  Handy, a married woman... I useta  fool with. Man, I kin sniff blondes  from a hunnert yards and redheads  from a mile and a half.
(to Tattoo) Drag's been chain-ganging so long  he's got a nose like a bloodhound.
Maybe he's been chain-ganging too  long.
Long enough to see redhots come and  redhots go.
The car begins to move away. They sigh. The work begins a

Time has passed; they are further down the road. A small  blue coupe kicks up dust as it jitters down the road and  stops across the highway before a small home. A blonde, m twenties, gets out, and heads covertly look up.
The woman is too much for them, too close, too blonde, to lush. They stop as one and watch as she disappears into t house.
Seeing their odd behavior, he turns to see what's happeni but the woman is gone; when he turns back, the men's head are back down.
Oh, man, did you see her? Did you  see her?
I got eyes, don't I? How my not gonna  see something like that?
Nice broad. Good set.
How could you tell? You could hardly  see her.
She's back!

Heads pop up again as the blonde comes out of the house, dressed in a short house dress, carrying a radio, a pail a sponge. She is clearly buxom. She goes to the outside  faucet, fills the bucket and drags the attached hose towa the car.
Look at that!
Shut up, you loudmouth jerk!
She begins to hose the dusty car, splashing herself, maki the cotton dress cling to her body, tossing her hair, eve movement and gesture erotic and provocative.
Their work is completely disorganized as they attempt to  shovel while watching. Their voices overlap.
Man Oh Man.
That is one mean lady. Bet her husband  spends one day a week shooting  milkmen.
Lookit her bounce.
Oh lean over here, lady. Lean this  way.
I wouldn't mind being that hose.
More... a little more.
I don't know if I believe it.
She's so big!
Now lean down... a little more.
Lookit that little honeypot. Lookit  those legs.
Oh man, I ain't never been so thirsty  in my life.
She begins to rub the windshield erotically.
Oh rub.
Rub.
Rub!
Rub-a-dub-dub. Rub-a-dub-dub.
I'm dyin'. I'm dyin'!
Look, she's got paint on her toenails!  Oh Lord, whatever I done, don't strike  me blind for 'nother couple minutes.  Oh you Lucille!
Lucille? Where do you get that?
(whirling) That'sa Lucille, you mullet head!  Any girl so innocent and built like  that gotta be named Lucille.
Innocent?
She don't even know what she's doin!.
She knows exactly what she's doin.  She's drivin' you crazy and lovin'  it.
Shut your mouth 'bout my Lucille.
Your Lucille? Man, you better put  them glasses back on and take a look  at yourself.
(glaring) Boy. You jus' asking to be handled!
as Godfrey moves across the scene, blocking their view,  staring at them, FILLING THE SCREEN.
Trashing bodies and heads in the steam. Feeling of tensio irritation, except for Babalugats, who is SINGING.
Babalugats, shut up.
Leave him alone. He's happy.
That's because he's a damn moron.
Now why don't you just shut up?
The men are in their bunks, sullen, quiet as the tire iro SOUNDS.
Awright, last bell.

Carr paces, counting. Beds SQUEAK as men turn restlessly, unable to get comfortable. At the far end of the barracks slow-turning fan CREAKS gratingly. It will continue to do throughout the scene, adding irritation to Carr's SQUEEGE steps and the regular SQUEAKING of bedsprings.
restless, irritated.
Fifty, Boss.
Fifty, right, Carr.
Man, it's so hot.
Gettin' up, Carr.
as Carr paces, SQUEEGEEING. The fan CREAKS. Springs SQUEA
Yeahhpp.
Gambler gets up, chains JANGLING.
uncomfortable, tense, shifting.
Giddyap, Carr.
Yeahhpp.
Tramp turns, irritated, as Carr SQUEEGEES by.
How can you sleep with that damn  squeaking!
Carr pacing. SQUEEGEEING, the fan CREAKING, springs SQUEA
Gettin' up, Carr.
Yeahhp.
Dynamite gets up, chains JANGLING.
It is turning slowly, CREAKING, CREAKING, CREAKING. And n on the SOUNDTRACK we HEAR low at first, but steadily buil the tinny SOUND of the Blonde Girl's radio.
tense, annoyed, frustrated as the SOUND of the RADIO GROW joining the CREAKING, SQUEAKING and SQUEEGEEING.
as Carr passes by. He speaks in a low whisper.
Man, that lil Lucille was a lot of  lil girl.
some turning away, not wanting to be reminded, some stari ahead unhappily, thinking the same thing.
You see how she was jus' poppin'  outa the top of that dress.
irritated, anxious.
Aw, come on, Drag.
not paying attention.
And down below, that thing didn't  reach no higher than... (chuckles) She liable to catch cold... runnin'  around like that.
irritated by Dragline's voice and the SQUEEGEEING and the SQUEAKING and CREAKING and the RADIO SOUND, tinny and gra growing in volume.
...And that thing was so tight 'cross  her bottom... made me wanna just  reach out my hands and...
Forget it, man.
suddenly angry.
Whatta you mean, forget it?
Stop beatin', man. You ain't doin'  nobody no good.
his face corroding in fury as the RADIO SOUND and the  CREAKING, SQUEAKING and SQUEEGEEING are at an unbearable  peak.
(with slow menace) Boy, you better get some sleep and  save your strength. 'Cause you're  gonna need it.
As the SOUNDS threaten to burst our ears with their high- pitched tension, the CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY into the hub of fan and our nerves scream for relief.

head_text.subj: LUKE AS GLOVE SMASHES INTO HIS FAC

text: (DAY)
and Luke falls back into the dirt. He's hurt, startled, b grins. We HEAR a CHEER from the men O.S., as he gets up. is stripped to the waist, wears huge 16 oz. boxing gloves

showing Dragline similarly dressed. They are squared off the yard, surrounded by YELLING men who want blood. It is release from the sexual tension built up by the night bef The guards stand in the guard boxes, watching. The Captai sits up on his porch, so he can see without being too obv Luke gets up and manages a lunging right across to Dragli Adam's apple. Dragline is momentarily staggered but count with a terrible clubbing blow that mashes Luke's gloves i his face, knocking him to the ground. Time is called for round.
as he gets to his feet.
Why don't you just stay there? He's  only gonna knock you down agin.
It's not your fault. He's just too  big.
Let him hit you in the nose, get  some blood flowing. Maybe they'll  stop it before he kills you.
(shaking his head,  grinning) I don't want to frighten him.
The second round is called and Luke advances toward Dragl

circling. Luke has to get in his shot before Dragline get too close and clubs him again. He feints a punch that mov Dragline off-balance and winds up for a big one, but Drag smashes him backhand. Luke hits the dirt, the men SCREAM YELL. Wiping some blood from his mouth, Luke rises again. is dizzy. Dragline smacks him down again.
SHOUTING, SHRIEKING, they have blood in their eyes, relea their tensions.

as the fight continues. The Captain on his porch rocks an spits dry little spouts of wind, Godfrey, impassive, wait in his guard house. The YELLING gradually subsides as Dra continues to smash Luke, who keeps getting up.
Without relish, he pokes Luke down again. Now there is no cheering, no yelling, just silence.
as he gets up and walks down to the wire where he can see what is happening. The silence disturbs him.
He rises, grinning and winds up to throw another punch. B the act of lifting his giant glove is a Herculean task.  Seconds go by in which he tries to raise the glove high e to launch a punch.
waiting, gloves at waist level, poised.
(low) Ommana pop you one easy. Stay down.
He pops Luke who reels, goes down on a knee and then slow rises, rises. Dragline is honestly agonized.
I'm gonna kill you, you go on...
That's what you're gonna have to do.
concerned.
impassive.

He raises his fists. But Luke is up again. Dragline reali he'll have to kill him to beat him. After a long moment,  Dragline drops his hands to his sides, looks back toward  Godfrey and the captain and then starts walking to the  barracks, fast.
He looks after him and reaches up to wipe the blood away, still grinning.

The poker game. Five card stud. Playing are Gambler, Koko Dynamite, Blind Dick and Luke, bandaged. The mood of the  barracks is quieter than usual. The men are still assessi the fight, uncertain as to who now is their leader, looki toward Dragline for an indication. Not playing, Dragline  lies on his bunk behind Koko, sullenly reading a sex book Gambler deals the third cards.
Ana paira ninas. Koko's the brains.
Cuter.
Dynamite is already out. Blind Dick now folds.
Ace calls.
Kick a buck.
(considers, then chips) I'm in.
Ace calls. Here we go. (deals Luke) King-five gets a tray for no help. (deals Koko) Paira ninas gets a Jack. (deals himself) Ana man with the ace gets... slop in  the face... Ninas up.
(regarding Luke) Cuter again.
Call.
(expressionless) Kick a buck.
Koko is worried. He looks at his hole card, considers, lo silence. Dragline looks over from his bunk.
(to Koko) Whatcha got?
Pair'a nines.
I kin see that, brick head. I mean  your hole card.
Koko hands it over his shoulder to Dragline, who now sits to consider the whole situation.
(continuing) Uh-huh. And he ain't got nothing  showing. Raise his head off.
He's been betting his head from the  gun. Gotta have kings.
So then you just call him.
(chipping) I call.
(studies Luke's cards) I gotta believe. Out! (folds) Now they're rollin'. (deals Luke) King-five-four gets an eight. (deals Koko) Pair'a nines with a Jack gets a four.  Ninas still up.
(tentatively) Cuter.
(automatically) Kick a buck.
Damn.
He looks up to Dragline for help.
Kick him back a buck!
Koko looks uncertain, but listens.
Back a buck.
(automatically) Kick a buck.
Koko looks up to Dragline: What do we do now?
Don't look at me, mullet-head.
Koko looks to the others.
Man, you play like a kokonut. You  got to call him at least.
I know he's got a paira kings. He  don't have to stick 'em in my ear.
Gotta have kings.
Sure he's got kings but you still  gotta call him.
Koko looks back to Dragline.
Man's got a paira kings, get your  tail out.
Koko folds. Luke reaches for the pot at the same time tha Dragline reaches for Luke's cards.
Nuthin'! A handfull of nuthin'! (cuffs Koko) You stupid mullet-head. He beat you  with nuthin'! Just like today when  he kept coming back at me.
(smiling) Nuthin' can be a pretty cool hand.
Cool Hand Luke.
So saying, Dragline saves face and the baton of leadershi is passed.

location: YOYO SHIMMERING IN THE SUN TRANSITIONAL DEVICE, (DAY)

text: swinging away the time...
SHOOTING THROUGH cage truck, as it moves swiftly along, t landscape a blur of shadows and racing phone poles, etc., the men shadows slouched on their benches inside.

This is a country road running over rolling moors, land o to the sky and sun, the roads reaching out to infinity. T cage truck rolls to the end of the road and stops. Stretc out on either side of the road, every five feet is a pyra of freshly dumped sand.
as the bull gang gets down, looks at the sand, are given  shovels.
Oh no, man! Not on this hot muther.
All the bears gonna be walking today.
(nervously) What's the deal?
Tar truck.
At these bleak words, over the last rise comes a filthy  blackened tank truck with a fire in its belly and an arra of pipes and valves at its rear, like a hellish beetle.
(to Tattoo, Tramp,  Alibi) You think you've been working hard.  This muther'll break your back.
This is a big day for the guards.  They get to remind us who's boss.
I ain't forgot.
as the truck driver makes adjustments in the heater, flam etc.
Awright, every second man, git to  the other side of the road.

Dragline, Dynamite, Gambler, Tattoo, Loudmouth Steve, Ali Sleepy, Stupid Blondie and Chief cross over, leaving Luke Koko, Society Red, Tramp, Babalugats, Blind Dick, Mechani and Sailor. The tar truck begins to move slowly down the  road, spreading a black, hot, acrid wake behind it.
(continuing; with  undisguised malice) Captain heard this gang been doin'  so good, gave us this special job.  We got three miles of tarrin' to  cover today. Let's roll it!

They begin to work, digging a shovel-full of sand, fannin it out over the hot tar, moving up to the next pile. Luke and Dragline in the lead of their respective groups. The  guards move up along the ridges behind the men, urging th to move faster, caning the slow workers.
Let's git with it!
Roll it, heah?
He is at the rear of the columns, walking down the center the road. With his stick he points to spots where the tar has not been covered and the nearest man flicks a spray o sand over it.

head_text.subj: ON LUKE WITH KOKO AND SOCIETY RED LATER

text: They are working steadily but it is hot, hard, back-break labor. Koko stops for a moment to rub his arm.
Oh man. I'm gonna twist my arm off  if this heat don't kill me first.
Boss Paul canes him across the legs.
Roll it!
sweating and suffering across the road, just keeping up w Luke.
Hey, buddy. Take it easy. You're  making me look bad.
The man wants speed, let's give it  to him. Ram it in and break it off.  Go hard. Shag it.
Dragline begins to work harder, digging and fanning, keep pace with Luke.
(panting) Whatta we racin' for?
Man wants speed, let's give it to  him. Use that shovel like you use  your spoon. Shag it, man!
Dynamite understands and throws himself into it.
up to their waists in smoke and dust, splattered with tar working like devils as the word passes down the line.
(to Society Red) Go hard!
(to Tattoo) Ram it in and break it off!
(to Sleepy) Roll it!
Shag it!
They are all working like hell.
He looks confused, concerned by this sudden manic activit
forced to walk faster to keep up, finding no unsanded spo for his sorcerer's wand.
enjoying the guard's confusion.
(to Luke) They don't know iff'n to smile, spit  or swallow.
They ain't never seen a bull gang  before.
Work those shovels instead of your  mouths.

Essentially a MONTAGE, a wild insane ballet of labor as l by Luke and Dragline, the bull gang throws itself into th madness, muttering Luke's words of inspiration to each ot and loving the guards' confusion. (SONG ON SOUND TRACK)
Go hard!
Ram it in...
Break it off...
Roll it!
Shag it!
Move it!

Luke grins and works. The guards are tense and uneasy and walk the road backward, not daring to turn their backs on these madmen. Rabbit runs around with his water bucket bu the men don't drink, just upturn the water over their fac and keep going.
confused, angry, has not been able to cane anyone in an h As Rabbit rushes by:
Rabbit! What the hell's goin' on?
(knows but isn't saying) I don't know, Boss. They must be  bearcaught. All of them.
He rushes off, as caught up in the esprit as the others.
More of the madness but now even faster, sweatier, wilder The men are bearcaught by their sudden power to confound guards. ALL SHOTS FAVORING Luke, splattered with tar, wor right behind the truck.
Replacing his stick with a rifle, as tense and uncertain the other bosses, staring at Luke with blank, hating eyes

as he looks up just as the tar truck turns off the road w has ended, crossed by a small highway. They have finished Luke stands straight, looking out across the highway to t rolling green beyond. Dragline works up to him.
Where'd the road go?
That's it. That's the end.
But there's still daylight left.
(checking the sun) 'Bout two hours left.
What do we do now?
Luke has been looking at the guards who have grouped in  conference around Boss Paul who has his watch out. They l concerned, gesticulating toward Luke and the others.
(smiling) Nothin'.
The others understand. They have beaten the Free Men by  working harder. They all collapse on the ground, rolling  about, dazed, tired but happy as hell, laughing.
Oh, Luke, you wild beautiful thing!  You crazy handful of nuthin'!

Sunday afternoon scene. The chain men are dancing, jingli Three RADIOS BLARE in different corners; a hell-fire prea where Deacon and Society Red sit working a letter; romant ballads (Near You, Heart Aches by Ted Weeks, etc.) for th men reading fuck books; rhythm and blues, country music f a couple of wrestlers, banging into bunks until one depan the other and runs off. CAMERA FOLLOWS THIS ACTION SHOWIN the scene. Other men rolling cigarettes, Dynamite still o his rattlesnake wallet, Koko cutting hair, using a board  over an ash can for a barber's chair. Everyone is barefoo
Visitor for Luke!
Luke sits up from his bunk, staring at the Wicker, unmovi amazed.
Steve. Your mother's here!
as he gets up. Behind him Loudmouth Steve gets up, tossin down his sex book resentfully:
Jeez! She never lets me alone.
You oughta be glad you got somebody.
Steve tosses him a finger as he leaves.
My wife hasn't been here for a month.  She must be sick again. She's had  this condition of the liver for...
Alibi, can't you never say nothin'  without explainin' it? Carr says you  even explain when you get up at night.

By the picnic table set up for visitors. In far b.g., we Luke come out of the door and start across the yard towar the gate, where he is shaken down and permitted to exit,  moving down to the table. A few feet from the end of the  table, Boss Godfrey sits in a kitchen chair, his hands  discreetly crossed over the pistol in his lap. His mirror eyes play over the scene. Loudmouth Steve, his MOTHER -- desperately fortyish blonde -- and a couple of other pris and visitors occupy the background. Parked next to the ta is a truck. In the bed lies Luke's mother, ARLETTA. She i propped up on pillows and wedged in for traveling. The whole back is set up as for a chronic invalid, everyt within reach, etc. She smokes incessantly. Nearby, Luke's BROTHER and his nephew, JOHN-BOY, a kid of twelve, enormo impressed with the sights and the guns and dogs, etc.
Comin' out here, Boss?
(by the gate) Yeah. Come on out, Luke.

A few feet outside the gate, Jackson reaches for the boy, pats him on the head. Shakes hands in passing with his  brother, who is unmistakably a farmer, and stands in the  doorway looking at his mother. She lies on her side crani to see him.
How'd you find me?
Helen, she sent along your things  with a note, and John here, he wrote  to the police.
Yeah. Well. (to Godfrey) Gettin' up here, Boss.
Godfrey just looks at him, says nothing.
Well, Arletta, I got to stand down  here.
I allus hoped to see you well fixed  and have me a crop of grandkids to  kiss and fuss around with.
Like to oblige you, Arletta, but  right off I don't know where to put  my hands on 'em.

Sometimes I wisht people was like  dogs, Luke. Comes a time, a day like,  when the bitch just don't recognize  her pups no more, so she don't have  no hopes nor love to bring her pain.  She just don't give a damn. They let  you smoke?
Smokin' it up here, Boss.
Boss Godfrey nods. He lights cigarettes for her and for  himself.
Yeah, well, Arletta, you done your  best. What I done with myself is my  problem.
No it hain't, Luke. You ain't alone.  Ever whar you go, I'm with you, and  so's John.
You never thought that's a heavy  load?
We allus thought you was strong enough  to carry it. Was we wrong?
Luke gives her the cigarette, and smiles at her.
No. But things ain't always like  they seem, Arletta. You know that. A  man's gotta go his own way.
Well, I don't know, I just wash my  hands of it, I guess I just got to  love you and let go.
She catches his hand as he puts the cigarette between her lips.
Yeah.
What are you doin' here?
We call it abuildin' time, Arletta.
I ain't askin' what you'll do after  you get out, because I'm gonna be  dead and it don't matter.
His mother's disappointment in him brings Jackson a real  twinge of pain here. He tries to change the subject.
You never wanted to live forever  anyways, did you? It wasn't such a  hell of a life.
Oh, I had me some high old times.  Yore old man, Luke, wasn't much for  stickin' around, but damn it he made  me laugh.
Yeah, would of been nice to of knowed  him, the way you talk about him.
She's looking at him and begins to laugh, losing control coughing to the point it alarms John and Jackson and they have to help her. She pays no attention to the cough.
He'd... He'd of... broke you up.
She quiets after the fit and lies back, tired.
You think life is some kind of ocean  voyage and you start out with buntin'  and hollerin' and high hopes, but  the damn ship goes down before you  ever reach the other side. Luke?
Here, Mom.
What went wrong?
Nothin'. Ever'thing's cool's can be.
No.
Tried to live always just as free  and aboveboard as you been, and well,  they ain't that much elbow room.
Arletta is looking hard into his eyes as he speaks. She  reaches out to him again...
You allus had good jobs, and that  girl in Kentucky I taken a shine to  her.
She took off with that convertible  feller...
Well, why not? Idee of marryin' got  you all choked up, trying to pretend  you was respectable you was borin'  the hell out of all of us.
(grinning at her) Yeah.
I'm leavin' the place to John.
That's good: he earned it.

Nothin' to do with it. I ain't never  give John the kind of feelin' I give  you, so I'm payin' him off now. Don't  feel you got to say anything. Way it  is, sometimes, you just have a feelin'  for a child or you don't, and with  John I just didn't.
Gotta go, Arletta.
(recovering) Laugh it up, kid. You'll make out.

She kneads his hand and subsides onto her bed. Luke turns away from her to face John, who has stood by. Godfrey is his feet. The other men are getting up and saying goodbye visitors, picking up their packages, etc., and among them a chain man, his chains dragging, holding them up with a  string. The kid stands by John looking at the chains clin past...
Why can't you have chains?
Luke looks up at John, Sr. with amusement.
Uncle Luke?
John-Boy looks to you. You're a hero.  He's braggin' on you all over the  county.
(thoughtful) Yeah.
You must've really flung a binge  this time. You really hit that cop?
(not liking the smug  pride in John) Much as I'd like to oblige you, John,  I didn't hit the cop. (beat) She's in pretty bad pain, ain't she?
(nods) Fulla dope, Luke.
Keep it with her all the time. Let  her have all she wants.
They understand each other. Luke chucks John-Boy under th chin, then stops, looks at John, kneels beside him.

You don't want to admire them chains,  John-Boy. They ain't medals. You get  them put on for makin' mistakes. (beat) And if you make a really bad mistake,  then you got to deal with the Man...  and he is one tough old boy.
Godfrey stares at them, his glasses mirroring.
So long, Arletta. Take care.
You know it, kid.
John holds Luke for a beat and reaches into the truck and pulls out a battered banjo which he gives Luke.
Now there's nothin' for you to come  back for.
LEAVING down the road, kicking up dust. Barracks in b.g.
cutting away at the time...

Suddenly there is an unidentifiable SOUND, low, but all the heads in the barra look up, waiting, silently. It has begun to rain, the big drops DRUMMING on the roof. It begins to fall heavily. You see mah skinny lid boy at chow  tonight. He was matching you plate  for plate.

Society Red is lying on his bunk looking at the bottom of the bunk above.
Oh, come on, Clarence.
Dragline sits up and looks at him aggressively.
What do you mean, Clarence? You  callin' me a liar?
He waits.
Not a liar. You just have a common --  and likable -- tendency toward  exaggeration.

(proudly) He's the champeen hog-gut of this  camp. Hell, I seen him eat ten  choc'lat bars and seven cold drinks  in fifteen minutes. He kin eat busted  bottles and rusty nails, any damn  thing. If you'd so kindly oblige as  to let me cut off your yankee head,  he'd even eat that.
I can eat fifty eggs.
They turn to look at him as though surprised to find him  there. Before Dragline can think he says...
Nobody kin eat fifty eggs.
(to Dragline) You just said he could eat anything.
(doubtfully, to Luke) You ever eat fifty eggs?
Nobody ever ate fifty eggs.
Bet! Bet! Babalugats!
Mah boy say he kin eat fifty eggs,  he'll eat fifty eggs.
Yeah but in how long?
One hour.
Well I believe I'll have to take  part of that wager.
Two bucks.
Let's talk money.
Awright, twenty bucks. Anything! The  Syndicate'll cover any money you  got. Koko, get paper.
Dragline... fifty eggs got to weigh  a good six pounds.
(expertly) Man's gut can't hold that. They'll  swell up and bust him open.
You're gonna kill him.
Getcha money, up. Gambler! Dynamite!  Everybody. Kokonut Head here is taking  the money. Loudmouth -- get it up!
The initial boredom of the scene is dispelled -- a purpos has been created to lead them through the endless buildin of time.
How's he gonna eat 'em?

Men are all around Dragline and Koko now with money and  wagers. Koko is frantically scribbling.
Koko, write down their names, don't  just make marks.
One rule! No throwing up. He throws  up, you forfeit everything.
You ever see mah boy throw up? Shut  your mouth and put up your money!
Koko is on the floor now with Babalugats beside him, asso papers, handing out betting receipts. Dragline turns to L
Why'd you have to say fifty? Why not  thirty-five or thirty-nine?
Fifty's a nice round number.
Damn, Luke. What's the matter with  you? what's the matter with me?
(winking) Nothin' to worry about. We got a  deadlock on that mullet.
Luke and Dragline jog around the yard like roadwork for a boxer and trainer.
What did I do? Stole and tole lies.  I loved mah neighbor and his wife,  but what did I do to deserve this  lunatic to come in mah happy home  and beat me outa hard earned bread.

Like an elephant.

taking enormous helpings.

as Dragline stops in front of the Wicker Man.

as the line of men reach the poker table and begin stacki up the eggs. The Rules Committee sits around the table le one side for Luke. It's all set up with towels, etc. They are counting eggs carefully, piling them in pyramids. Dra picks up an egg and cracks it smartly on the table. Again uproar...

looking at him, neutral...

You're a sweet old boy and I don't  like to see you pick up no bad habits.  Better use that dollar to buy yourself  a new spark plug or something. But  as long as you done took a stand,  why don't you put some money where  your mouth is? Not no measly buck!

with a herculean effort, he swallows.

as Dragline stands behind him, massaging his shoulders an neck, tenderly... Luke doggedly eats eggs, one by one. Re counts off under...

Six minutes to go, Dragline.
(into Luke's ear) Just shakin' it down, that's all,  settlin' them eggs down...
He sits him down, takes an egg from Koko and puts it to L lips, pursing his lips in a kiss...
Come on, Baby... don't be that way.  Open your little ol' gator mouth.
Luke opens his mouth, in goes the egg, he chews, chews,  swallows. Another egg...
Forty-four...
Two minutes to time...
All right now: get mad at them eggs.  Eat it there boy! Bite it! Gnaw on  it!
Forty-five.
One minute, thirty seconds.
Another egg goes. Luke closes his eyes and motions to  Dragline; just stuff 'em in any old how!

All eggs peeled, Koko is up and dancing wildly, and a cou of men, even though they've got nothing but everything to lose, are intoxicated beyond power to restrain themselves and are yelling and jumping up and down.
One minute, fifty-five... fifty...  forty-five... etc.
Forty-five, forty-six, forty-seven...

So that it all comes out in a near dead-heat, with Dragli yelling and popping in eggs. At the last second before  deadline, two whole eggs are shoved into Luke's mouth, an Dragline rams Luke's mouth shut for him...
All in: that's it: chew, chew, chew!
Fifteen, ten, nine, eight, seven...  six...
Luke looks around, then takes a mighty swallow, as:
One... zero!
Luke collapses with his head on the table, his arms flung out.
He didn't swallow the last...
He grabs him by the hair and pulls his head back. Draglin pries his mouth open with his fingers. Luke is out...
You think so, huh?
as they all peer down into his throat. Dragline grins, lo around at Society.
Where's the egg?

He slaps Luke on the cheek affectionately, closes his mou and lets his head fall back on the table with a loud thum his arms again sprawled out in the piles of egg shells. A dance of victory for Dragline... he collects all over the place. Dynamite, shaking his head, quietly knights the ne champion hog-gut by laying his big spoon on the table nex to Luke's head.
A car ROARS by, leaving a hint of laughter and music in t air and a cloud of dust. The men are working rhythmically Godfrey watching.
They have been observing Godfrey.
Man looks like a goddamn bus driver.
(yoyoing) He gets too close to me and I'll cut  his belly open.
He sees snake.
Snake in the grass! Boss!
He runs. Men flail at the snake in the grass with their y and CAMERA MOVES WITH Snake though we can't see it and we follow its progress only by the men jumping, hitting at i yelling.

Pickin' it up here, Boss!

His EYES HUGE IN THE SCREEN: Luke seen there IN DUPLICATE standing tall in the sun, grinning, the rattler wriggling and thrashing in his grasp. Godfrey's face holds for a lo beat then the rifle is brought up so that we can now see  Luke CLEAR IN ONE LENS and the other he is lined up in th rifle sight pointing directly INTO THE LENS -- or just CA LEFT. There is a SHOT and the rifle is lowered enough so can see Luke IN DUPLICATE again.

looking at Godfrey, grinning, but a little tougher now. T snake has no head. He walks down a little and throws the  body of the snake on the road at Godfrey's feet. It bring him close to where Godfrey's cane still stands in the san Godfrey kicks at the snake. He turns... Luke pulls the ca out of the sand and holds it out to Godfrey.

Godfrey turns to face him and stares at him. Luke just ho the stick out to him. Godfrey slowly takes the bolt out o the rifle, looks down the barrel, blows the smoke out, pu the bolt in his pocket and hands the gun back to Rabbit b finally reaching out and taking the stick from Luke. He t and walks away.
You shore can shoot, man.

working.

Luke, why you actin' so strange?  What you wanna do somethin' like  that for? You gone too far when you  mess with the Man With No Eyes. You  gonna be outa here in a little bit --  whyn't you jus' take it a little  easy?
Luke has been staring up at the darkening sky which is gr more ominous with clashing clouds and rolling thunder.
Man, it looks like the Big Boss is  getting ready to let us have it!
It begins to rain, large spattering drops, quickly turnin into a downpour.
Awright, you kin git in that truck.
The gang rushes back into the shelter, all except Luke an Dragline.
Look at Him go. Bam! Bam!
Knock it off, Luke! You cain't talk  about Him that way.
Dragline begins to move off toward the truck.
You still believe in the Big Bearded  Boss, Drag? You think he's up there  watching us?
He grins at Dragline and then, after a beat, raises his b axe straight up to the sky, grinning at Dragline.
He is frightened as he backs off toward the truck.
Get in here! Ain't you scared --  ain't you scared of dyin'?
The rain is torrential. He has to shout to be heard.
Dyin'? He can take back this nice  pretty life any time He wants. (looks up) You welcome to it, Old Timer. Come  on! Make me know you're up there!  Kill me or love me, one or the other.
He holds his bush axe again, laughing, soaking wet.
The men jammed into the frame of the body, a frieze of sh faces staring out at him through the rain. There is a bli flash of lightning and a THUNDEROUS ROAR. They wince but  don't turn away.
He smiles and lowers the bush axe, walking toward the tru
Standin' out here in the rain! All  alone! Talkin' to myself.
He smiles a little shamefaced, rueful, sad smile and clim into the truck and the men draw back from him.
Godfrey seen dimly through the rain-misted windshield.

Borrowin'.
Mister Cool Hand here is the soft  heart in our Loan Department. Next!
He has just been handed a telegram by the Wicker Man. He  reads it impassive as always, while in b.g., the business continues and we HEAR:
I believe I still owe you thirty. I  don't suppose you'd take a check.
(to Luke) My Navy disability didn't come yet.  You know how it is.
Carr finishes reading and we FOLLOW HIM as he walks to th table.
Sure do... that's why we didn't bet  with the Navy.
Oh, that's mah darlin' Luke. Grins  like a baby and bites like a 'gator.

Sorry, Luke.
Luke picks up the telegram and reads. Then he sets it dow stands and goes to his bunk. Dragline looks after him, ta up the telegram and hands it up to Society Red.

sitting on his bunk, bare feet tucked up beneath his draw up legs, softly picking out a slow hymn melody on his ban Tears slowly stream down his cheeks.
as Luke continues playing softly. He walks down to the ot end of the barracks, too.

playing, the tears coursing.
in his bunk now, staring wet-eyed up at the ceiling.

Luke, fall out.

(emotionless) When a man's mother dies and he gits  to thinkin' about her funeral and  payin' respects, before he knows it  his mind ain't right and he's got  rabbit in his blood and runs. We're  keepin' you off the road fer awhile.

(to Luke) Ah'm jus' doin' mah job, Luke. You  gotta appreciate that.

listening to the mocking voice.

Git on your feet! Ah'm gonna teach  you some respect right now!

protecting, as Boss Paul retreats. The box door slams!  Greyness.
as the bull gang counts in after the day's work. The ligh on the box still burns. No sound from Luke.
